title: How much land would be covered by the plants that turned into the fossil fuels humanity has burned? - Quora

response.answer_text: Here are the numbers: (Sorry for the American units, but that’s what I grew up with.) The atmospheric pressure is 15 pounds per square inch. Oxygen makes up 21% of that, so 3.2 pounds of oxygen exists above every square inch of the globe. If we wanted to remove all that oxygen, we’d need 1.2 pounds of carbon to react with those 3.2 pounds of oxygen. (12 weight of carbon reacts with 32 weight of oxygen to produce carbon dioxide — perhaps American units make things easy on us;-) So, if we use anthracite coal, which has a density about that of water, we’d have to cover the world, ocean and land, with about a meter thickness of carbon to oxidize all the oxygen in the atmosphere. Oh, wait — you only wanted the fossil fuels we burned. We’ve added about 200 ppm of carbon dioxide since the industrial revolution, so we’ve only burned about a thousandth of the buried carbon. So, a millimeter layer of carbon across the globe represents the plants that made those fossil fuels we burned.
